If $x ‚â§ f x$ for all $x$ (we write this as `id ‚â§ f`), then the same is true for any iterate
`f^[n]` of `f`.

type: ‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : Preorder Œ±] {f : Œ± ‚Üí Œ±}, id ‚â§ f ‚Üí ‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï), id ‚â§ f^[n]
name: Function.id_le_iterate_of_id_le
docString:
If $x ‚â§ f x$ for all $x$ (we write this as `id ‚â§ f`), then the same is true for any iterate
`f^[n]` of `f`.

For any natural numbers $n$ and $a$ with $a \leq 2n$, we have $\sqrt{n^2 + a} = n$.

type: ‚àÄ {a : ‚Ñï} (n : ‚Ñï), a ‚â§ n + n ‚Üí (n * n + a).sqrt = n
name: Nat.sqrt_add_eq
docString: For any natural numbers $n$ and $a$ with $a \leq 2n$, we have $\sqrt{n^2 + a} = n$.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n` and for any other natural number `a` such that `a` is less than or equal to twice `n`, the square root (calculated using the `Nat.sqrt` function) of the sum of the square of `n` and `a` is equal to `n`. In mathematical notation, this is stating that for all $n, a \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $a \leq 2n$, we have $\sqrt{n^2 + a} = n$.

type: ‚àÄ {a : ‚Ñï} (n : ‚Ñï), a ‚â§ n + n ‚Üí (n * n + a).sqrt = n
name: Nat.sqrt_add_eq
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n` and for any other natural number `a` such that `a` is less than or equal to twice `n`, the square root (calculated using the `Nat.sqrt` function) of the sum of the square of `n` and `a` is equal to `n`. In mathematical notation, this is stating that for all $n, a \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $a \leq 2n$, we have $\sqrt{n^2 + a} = n$.

The monotone sequence whose value at `n` is the supremum of the `f m` where `m ‚â§ n`.

type: {Œ± : Type u_1} ‚Üí [inst : SemilatticeSup Œ±] ‚Üí (‚Ñï ‚Üí Œ±) ‚Üí ‚Ñï ‚Üío Œ±
name: partialSups
docString: The monotone sequence whose value at `n` is the supremum of the `f m` where `m ‚â§ n`.

For all natural numbers m and n, if m <= n then m^2 <= n^2.

type: ‚àÄ {m n : ‚Ñï}, m ‚â§ n ‚Üí m * m ‚â§ n * n
name: Nat.mul_self_le_mul_self
docString: For all natural numbers m and n, if m <= n then m^2 <= n^2.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the square of its integer square root (calculated using the `Nat.sqrt` function) is less than or equal to `n` itself. In other words, for all `n` in the set of natural numbers, the inequality $(\text{Nat.sqrt } n)^2 \leq n$ holds. This is a property of integer square roots, reflecting the fact that they are the largest whole number whose square does not exceed the original number.

type: ‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï), n.sqrt * n.sqrt ‚â§ n
name: Nat.sqrt_le
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the square of its integer square root (calculated using the `Nat.sqrt` function) is less than or equal to `n` itself. In other words, for all `n` in the set of natural numbers, the inequality $(\text{Nat.sqrt } n)^2 \leq n$ holds. This is a property of integer square roots, reflecting the fact that they are the largest whole number whose square does not exceed the original number.

A Cauchy sequence on the natural numbers is bounded.

type: ‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u} [inst : PseudoMetricSpace Œ±] {u : ‚Ñï ‚Üí Œ±}, CauchySeq u ‚Üí ‚àÉ R > 0, ‚àÄ (m n : ‚Ñï), dist (u m) (u n) < R
name: cauchySeq_bdd
docString: A Cauchy sequence on the natural numbers is bounded.

If `dist (f n) (f (n+1))` is bounded by `(C / 2) / 2^n`, then `f` is a Cauchy sequence.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : PseudoMetricSpace Œ±] (C : ‚Ñù) {f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí Œ±},
  (‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï), dist (f n) (f (n + 1)) ‚â§ C / 2 / 2 ^ n) ‚Üí CauchySeq f
name: cauchySeq_of_le_geometric_two
docString: If `dist (f n) (f (n+1))` is bounded by `(C / 2) / 2^n`, then `f` is a Cauchy sequence.

A function `f` on `Fin (n + 1)` is monotone if and only if `f i ‚â§ f (i + 1)` for all `i`.

type:
‚àÄ {n : ‚Ñï} {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : Preorder Œ±] {f : Fin (n + 1) ‚Üí Œ±},
  Monotone f ‚Üî ‚àÄ (i : Fin n), f (Fin.castSucc i) ‚â§ f (Fin.succ i)
name: Fin.monotone_iff_le_succ
docString: A function `f` on `Fin (n + 1)` is monotone if and only if `f i ‚â§ f (i + 1)` for all `i`.

The square of the smallest prime factor of a composite number `n` is at most `n`.

type: ‚àÄ {n : ‚Ñï}, 0 < n ‚Üí ¬¨Nat.Prime n ‚Üí Nat.minFac n ^ 2 ‚â§ n
name: Nat.minFac_sq_le_self
docString: The square of the smallest prime factor of a composite number `n` is at most `n`.

Linear upper bound for `f (x + n)` on unit interval

type:
‚àÄ {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {x : ‚Ñù} {n : ‚Ñï},
  ConvexOn ‚Ñù (Set.Ioi 0) f ‚Üí
    (‚àÄ {y : ‚Ñù}, 0 < y ‚Üí f (y + 1) = f y + Real.log y) ‚Üí n ‚â† 0 ‚Üí 0 < x ‚Üí x ‚â§ 1 ‚Üí f (‚Üën + x) ‚â§ f ‚Üën + x * Real.log ‚Üën
name: Real.BohrMollerup.f_add_nat_le
docString: Linear upper bound for `f (x + n)` on unit interval

If the sequence with `n`-th term the the sup norm of `Œª x, f (x + n)` on the interval `Icc 0 1`,
for `n ‚àà ‚Ñ§`, is summable, then `f` is integrable on `‚Ñù`.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] {f : C(‚Ñù, E)},
  (Summable fun n => ‚ÄñContinuousMap.restrict (Set.Icc 0 1) (ContinuousMap.comp f (ContinuousMap.addRight ‚Üën))‚Äñ) ‚Üí
    MeasureTheory.Integrable ‚áëf
name: Real.integrable_of_summable_norm_Icc
docString:
If the sequence with `n`-th term the the sup norm of `Œª x, f (x + n)` on the interval `Icc 0 1`,
for `n ‚àà ‚Ñ§`, is summable, then `f` is integrable on `‚Ñù`.

name: Monotone.iterate_le_of_le
docString: If `f ‚â§ g` and `f` is monotone, then `f^[n] ‚â§ g^[n]`.

Linear lower bound for `f (x + n)` on unit interval

type:
‚àÄ {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {x : ‚Ñù} {n : ‚Ñï},
  ConvexOn ‚Ñù (Set.Ioi 0) f ‚Üí
    (‚àÄ {y : ‚Ñù}, 0 < y ‚Üí f (y + 1) = f y + Real.log y) ‚Üí 2 ‚â§ n ‚Üí 0 < x ‚Üí f ‚Üën + x * Real.log (‚Üën - 1) ‚â§ f (‚Üën + x)
name: Real.BohrMollerup.f_add_nat_ge
docString: Linear lower bound for `f (x + n)` on unit interval

From an upper bound on `sqrtTwoAddSeries 0 n = 2 cos (œÄ / 2 ^ (n+1))` of the form
`sqrtTwoAddSeries 0 n ‚â§ 2 - (a / 2 ^ (n + 1)) ^ 2)`, one can deduce the lower bound `a < œÄ`
thanks to basic trigonometric inequalities as expressed in `pi_gt_sqrtTwoAddSeries`.

type: ‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï) {a : ‚Ñù}, Real.sqrtTwoAddSeries (‚Üë0 / ‚Üë1) n ‚â§ 2 - (a / 2 ^ (n + 1)) ^ 2 ‚Üí a < Real.pi

docString:
From an upper bound on `sqrtTwoAddSeries 0 n = 2 cos (œÄ / 2 ^ (n+1))` of the form

Statement of Graham's conjecture (which is now a theorem in the literature).

Graham's conjecture states that if $0 < a_1 < \dots a_n$ are integers, then
$\max_{i, j} \frac{a_i}{\gcd(a_i, a_j)} \ge n$.

type: ‚Ñï ‚Üí (‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï) ‚Üí Prop
name: Nat.GrahamConjecture
docString:
Statement of Graham's conjecture (which is now a theorem in the literature).

Graham's conjecture states that if $0 < a_1 < \dots a_n$ are integers, then
$\max_{i, j} \frac{a_i}{\gcd(a_i, a_j)} \ge n$.

From a lower bound on `sqrtTwoAddSeries 0 n = 2 cos (œÄ / 2 ^ (n+1))` of the form
`2 - ((a - 1 / 4 ^ n) / 2 ^ (n + 1)) ^ 2 ‚â§ sqrtTwoAddSeries 0 n`, one can deduce the upper bound
`œÄ < a` thanks to basic trigonometric formulas as expressed in `pi_lt_sqrtTwoAddSeries`.

type:
‚àÄ (n : ‚Ñï) {a : ‚Ñù},
  2 - ((a - 1 / 4 ^ n) / 2 ^ (n + 1)) ^ 2 ‚â§ Real.sqrtTwoAddSeries (‚Üë0 / ‚Üë1) n ‚Üí 1 / 4 ^ n ‚â§ a ‚Üí Real.pi < a
name: Real.pi_upper_bound_start
docString:
From a lower bound on `sqrtTwoAddSeries 0 n = 2 cos (œÄ / 2 ^ (n+1))` of the form
`2 - ((a - 1 / 4 ^ n) / 2 ^ (n + 1)) ^ 2 ‚â§ sqrtTwoAddSeries 0 n`, one can deduce the upper bound
`œÄ < a` thanks to basic trigonometric formulas as expressed in `pi_lt_sqrtTwoAddSeries`.

If a function admits a finite power series expansion bounded by `n`, then it is equal to
the `m`th partial sums of this power series at every point of the disk for `n ‚â§ m`.

type:
‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} {F : Type u_3} [inst : NontriviallyNormedField ùïú] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : NormedSpace ùïú E] [inst_3 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_4 : NormedSpace ùïú F] {f : E ‚Üí F}
  {p : FormalMultilinearSeries ùïú E F} {x : E} {r : ENNReal} {n : ‚Ñï},
  HasFiniteFPowerSeriesOnBall f p x n r ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ y ‚àà EMetric.ball 0 r, ‚àÄ (m : ‚Ñï), n ‚â§ m ‚Üí f (x + y) = FormalMultilinearSeries.partialSum p m y
name: HasFiniteFPowerSeriesOnBall.eq_partialSum
docString:
If a function admits a finite power series expansion bounded by `n`, then it is equal to
the `m`th partial sums of this power series at every point of the disk for `n ‚â§ m`.

If `f : ‚Ñï ‚Üí Œ±` has sum `a`, then the partial sums `‚àë_{i=0}^{n-1} f i` converge to `a`.

type:
